Using floor like that wouldn't return the correct values for negative numbers:
select trunc(-29.99);

expected:  -29
got:       -30
Same floor issue with negative numbers as described before.
not sure if we really need this additional integration tests, I think the scalar unit tests are enough. Or do I miss some by unit tests not covered scenarios?
I agree, the unit tests should cover all scenarios.
Is this worth having 2 implementations? Maybe we can just use 1 with a default val of 0.
all input args must be checked for NULL values, otherwise this results in an NPE.

this should result in  isLiteral(29L).
in general, normalizing using literals should always result in a literal, pls fix all normalize tests here please.
should result in isLiteral(null, DataTypes.LONG)

have a look at the other sections in this document. the style we've used for other functions is to have an intro para that explains what the function does and uses the argument literals in the explanation text
for example:
``power(a: number, b: number)``
-------------------------------

Returns the given argument ``a`` raised to the power of argument ``b``.

could you reword this so it follows the same style?

nodes.bodyText: don't we want to treat trunc(number, 0) the same as trunc(number)?  At least pgsql behaves like this..
You can use BaseFunctionResolver.
thank you for that
why do we need to assert it here, FunctionResolver#getSignature does it already.
would it be simpler to replace it with UnaryScalar and BinaryScalar, so we can delegate null checks and inputs materialization to those classes.

we can add a new ctor like:
BinaryScalar(BinaryOperator<T> func, String name, List<DataType<T>> argTypes, DataType<T> returnType)

but maybe too much for this PR

I think, I'd prefer to use a dedicated UnaryScalar for the 1 argument case, with 2 args we could always use the BigDecimal.valueOf(val).setScale(numDecimals, mode).doubleValue() logic, even with precision 0 it should work as defined.
I'd use the concrete scalar impl only for the 2 args case. Adjusting the BinaryScalar to support different argtypes and return types violates a bit its semantic imho.
